[
   {
     "sid": "50094",
     "Technique ID": "T1593",
     "Technique Name": "Poisoning",
     "Quotes": "Adversaries may poison a cache, data, or repository to cause poisoning-related effects on future operations and actions.",
     "Explanation": "This rule detects attempts to poison HTTP response caches by injecting malicious content into the cache using the Responder tool."
   }
 ][
 "sid": "50094",
 "Technique ID": "T1583",
 "Technique name": "Responder Poisoning",
 "Quotes": "Adversaries may configure a host to respond to NetBIOS name service (NBT-NS) poison queries, which can result in targeting other hosts on the network to spoof traffic and redirect it through a rogue responder.",
 "Explanation": "This rule detects attempts to poison DNS responses by modifying the HOSTS file."
 ][
     "Sid": "50094",
     "Technique ID": "T1498",
     "Technique name": "Malicious Link",
     "Quotes": "Adversaries may send malicious links via phishing, malicious websites, or other means in an attempt to trick users into clicking on them to download malware, execute malicious code, or spread malware.",
     "Explanation": "This rule looks for traffic containing a malicious link that attempts to download malicious content from a remote server."
 ][
     "sid": "50094",
     "Technique ID": "T1497",
     "Technique name": "Endpoint Denial of Service",
     "Quotes": "Adversaries can perform DoS attacks against any software or hardware endpoint.",
     "Explanation": "This rule targets attempts to launch an endpoint DoS attack by exploiting a vulnerability in the Responder service."
 ][
   {
     "sid": "50094",
     "Technique ID": "T1541",
     "Technique name": "Poisoning",
     "Quotes": "Adversaries may modify the contents of network traffic or data stores to return false or malicious information or otherwise disrupt normal operations.",
     "Explanation": "This rule detects attempts to poison the DNS cache using the Responder tool, which can redirect users to malicious websites."
   }
 ][
   {
     "sid": "50094",
     "Technique ID": "T1190",
     "Technique Name": "Exploit Public-Facing Application",
     "Quotes": "Adversaries may attempt to exploit a weakness in an Internet-facing host or system to initially access a network.",
     "Explanation": "This rule looks for attempts to exploit a vulnerability in web servers that allows an attacker to execute arbitrary code by sending a specially crafted HTTP request. The rule specifically looks for requests that attempt to access a file named \"logo.jpg\" from a directory named \"RespProxySrv\". This technique is often used by adversaries to gain initial access to a network."
   },
   {
     "sid": "50094",
     "Technique ID": "T1210",
     "Technique Name": "Exploitation of Remote Services",
     "Quotes": "Adversaries may exploit remote services to gain unauthorized access to internal systems once inside of a network.",
     "Explanation": "This rule looks for attempts to exploit a vulnerability in a remote service that allows an attacker to execute arbitrary code. The rule specifically looks for requests that attempt to access a file named \"logo.jpg\" from a directory named \"RespProxySrv\". This technique is often used by adversaries to gain initial access to a network."
   }
 ][
     {
         "sid": "50094",
         "Technique ID": "T1540",
         "Technique Name": "Poisoning",
         "Quotes": "Adversaries may poison data sources or content to manipulate searches or subsequent actions.",
         "Explanation": "This rule detects a poisoning attack on a Responder."
     },
     {
         "sid": "50094",
         "Technique ID": "T1656",
         "Technique Name": "Impersonation",
         "Quotes": "Adversaries may impersonate a trusted person or organization in order to persuade and trick a target into performing some action on their behalf.",
         "Explanation": "This rule detects an attempt to impersonate a Responder."
     }
 ][
   {
     "sid": "50094",
     "Technique ID": "T1497",
     "Technique Name": "Virtualization/Sandbox Evasion",
     "Quotes": "Adversaries may employ various means to detect and avoid virtualization and analysis environments",
     "Explanation": "The rule looks for attempts to load a file using a special syntax (file:\\) which might be used to evade sandbox environments."
   }
 ][
   {
     "sid": "50094",
     "Technique ID": "T1540",
     "Technique name": "Responder Poisoning",
     "Quotes": "Adversaries may poison the NetBIOS Name Service (NBNS) cache with malicious or compromised DNS, DHCP, or WINS server records to redirect legitimate traffic to an attacker-controlled location.",
     "Explanation": "The rule detects Responder poisoning attempts, such as injecting malicious DNS records into the NBNS cache to redirect traffic to attacker-controlled systems."
   }
 ][
     "sid": "50094",
     "Technique ID": "T1498",
     "Technique name": "Responder Beacon",
     "Quotes": "Adversaries may abuse the Responder service, typically on Windows systems, for the creation of a covert channel or to establish a remote access connection.",
     "Explanation": "This rule detects attempts to poison Responder service, which can be used to redirect traffic to an attacker-controlled system."
 ][
     "sid": "50094",
     "Technique ID": "T1497",
     "Technique name": "Port Scanning",
     "Quotes": "Adversaries may scan ports to identify open or listening ports on a network. These ports may be used for communication between hosts or for providing services.",
     "Explanation": "This rule looks for a pattern that is commonly used in HTTP attacks to poison a Responder Proxy Server, which could allow an adversary to gain unauthorized access to a network."
 ]

{10096: '[
        "sid": "10096",
        "Technique ID": "T1056",
        "Technique Name": "Input Capture",
        "Quotes": ""Input Capture techniques involve intercepting and capturing user input data, such as keystrokes, to obtain sensitive information. This rule detects an attack by a keylogger (win32.remotekeylog.b) attempting to capture keystrokes, which aligns with the objective of Input Capture techniques to obtain input data for malicious purposes."",
        "Explanation": "Keyloggers are typically used to capture and exfiltrate sensitive information, such as passwords and other credentials, making Input Capture a relevant technique."
    ]'}

     "Technique Name": "Web Shell",
     "Quotes": "\"Web shells are malicious scripts, usually encoded, that adversaries upload to a compromised web server. Once uploaded, an adversary can use the web shell to execute commands on, interact with, and potentially gain control of the compromised system.\"",
     "Explanation": "This rule looks for a malicious web shell to execute commands on the server."
   },
   {
     "sid": "37245",
     "Technique ID": "T1100",
     "Technique Name": "Compromise Infrastructure",
     "Quotes": "\"Adversaries may attempt to compromise infrastructure by targeting internet-facing services to establish initial footholds into a network.\"",

   },
   {

     "Technique Name": "Data Encrypted for Impact",
     "Quotes": "\"Adversaries may use encryption to evade detection of their malicious content.\"",
     "Explanation": "The web shell may use encryption to evade detection."
   }
 ][

Web shells are often used to bypass authentication mechanisms and execute arbitrary commands on the compromised system\"",

         "Explanation": "This rule detects a connection to a remote access server."
     ],

         "Technique ID": "T1132",
         "Technique name": "Data Encoding",
         "Quotes": "\"Adversaries may encode data to evade detection, conceal its true purpose, or prevent analysis\"",

 ][

 }
 ][

     "sid": "37245",
     "Technique ID": "T1001",
     "Technique name": "Remote Access Software",
     "Quotes": "Adversaries may use a Remote Access Trojan (RAT), which is a type of malware that allows remote control of victim systems, for a variety of malicious purposes, including data exfiltration, lateral movement, and command and control.",
     "Explanation": "This rule looks for activity associated with the Chopper web shell, which is a type of RAT that allows attackers to remotely control victim systems."
   },
   {
     "sid": "37245",
     "Technique ID": "T1100",
     "Technique name": "Web Shell",
     "Quotes": "Adversaries may use web shells to execute arbitrary system commands, upload and download files, and interact with the system.",

     "Technique name": "Data Exfiltration",

 ][

     "Technique ID": "T1001",
     "Technique name": "Web Shell",
     "Quotes": ""Web shells are malicious scripts or programs that provide an adversary a remote administrative interface to a compromised system via HTTP or HTTPS. Web shells can be used for a variety of malicious purposes, including the execution of arbitrary commands, the download and upload of arbitrary files, and the compromise of additional systems."",
     "Explanation": "This rule identifies connections to a web shell, which is a malicious script or program that provides an adversary with a remote administrative interface to a compromised system via HTTP or HTTPS."
   },
   {
     "sid": "37245",
     "Technique ID": "T1100",
     "Technique name": "Remote System Discovery",
     "Quotes": ""A remote system is a system that is connected to a local network, but is not physically present at the same location. Remote systems can be accessed through various methods such as remote desktop protocol (RDP) or virtual private network (VPN)."",
     "Explanation": "This rule can be used to detect reconnaissance activities, such as attempts to discover and enumerate remote systems on a network."
   },

     "Technique ID": "T1132",
     "Technique name": "Data Exfiltration",
     "Quotes": ""Data exfiltration techniques are used by adversaries to move data from a victim system to a remote system. Exfiltration techniques can be used to steal sensitive data, such as financial information, intellectual property, or personally identifiable information."",
     "Explanation": "This rule can be used to detect data exfiltration attempts, such as attempts to transfer sensitive data from a victim system to a remote system."
   }
 ][
         "sid": "37245",
         "Technique ID": "T1132",
         "Technique name": "External Remote Service",
         "Quotes": "Adversaries may leverage external-facing remote services to initially access and/or persist within a network.",

     ],

     "Technique name": "Ingress Tool Transfer",

   },

     "Technique ID": "T1001",
     "Technique name": "Web Shell",
     "Quotes": "Adversaries may use web shells to obtain a remote shell or command execution capability on a compromised system.",
     "Explanation": "This rule detects a connection to a known web shell associated with Win.Backdoor.Chopper, indicating an attempt to establish a remote shell or command execution capability."
   }
 ][
   {
     "sid": "37245", 
     "Technique ID": "T1100", 
     "Technique name": "Web Shell", 
     "Quotes": "Adversaries may deploy a web shell to provide remote access to a compromised host, enabling unauthorized control of the system. This technique allows an adversary to execute commands, upload and download files, and modify the configuration of the compromised system.", 
     "Explanation": "The rule looks for activity associated with the Chopper web shell, which is commonly used by attackers to gain remote access to compromised systems."
   }, 
   {
     "sid": "37245", 
     "Technique ID": "T1132", 
     "Technique name": "Direct Web Requests", 
     "Quotes": "Adversaries may use direct web requests to interact with web applications and services on the target network by sending HTTP or HTTPS requests directly to the target host. This technique allows the adversary to bypass normal authentication and authorization mechanisms and to exploit vulnerabilities in the web application or service.", 
     "Explanation": "The rule looks for POST requests containing suspicious data, which is a common method used by attackers to interact with web shells."
   }
 ][
   {

     "Technique ID": "T1100",
     "Technique Name": "Web Shell",
     "Quotes": "Adversaries may use web shells to maintain persistent access and compromise a web application through interactive command execution.",
     "Explanation": "This rule detects the use of a web shell to connect to a backdoor on a compromised system."
   },
   {
     "sid": "37245",
     "Technique ID": "T1132",
     "Technique Name": "Direct Web Requests",
     "Quotes": "Adversaries may make direct requests to web servers to interact with web applications or an underlying environment. This technique encompasses a wide range of HTTP-based activities, including testing for vulnerabilities, exploiting web application vulnerabilities, and exfiltrating data.",
     "Explanation": "This rule detects the use of a web shell to make direct requests to a web server."
   }
 ][
   {
     "sid": "37245",
     "Technique ID": "T1001",
     "Technique name": "Data Obfuscation",
     "Quotes": ""Adversaries may obfuscate command and control traffic to make it more difficult to detect."",
     "Explanation": "This rule detects web shell activity associated with the Chopper backdoor, which is known to use data obfuscation techniques to hide its communications"
   },

     "sid": "37245",
     "Technique ID": "T1100",
     "Technique name": "Web Shell",
     "Quotes": ""Adversaries may use a web shell to execute arbitrary commands and interact with a compromised system."",

   },

     "Technique ID": "T1132",
     "Technique name": "Data Encoding",
     "Quotes": ""Adversaries may encode data to make the content of command and control traffic more difficult to detect."",
     "Explanation": "This rule includes a reference to base64 decoding, which is a common data encoding technique used by adversaries to hide malicious content within web requests."
   }
 ][

     "Technique ID": "T1001",
     "Technique Name": "Web Shell",
     "Quotes": "Adversaries may use a web shell to maintain access to a compromised system over HTTP or HTTPS. Web shells are often used to provide adversary-controlled remote access to a system or to facilitate the download of additional tools or malware.",

[
   {
     "sid": "56614",
     "Technique ID": "T1218",
     "Technique Name": "System Binary Proxy Execution",
     "Quotes": "Adversaries may bypass process and/or signature-based defenses by proxying execution of malicious content with signed, or otherwise trusted, binaries.",
     "Explanation": "Cobalt Strike uses legitimate system tools and protocols to evade detection and maintain persistence on compromised systems."
   },
   {
     "sid": "56614",
     "Technique ID": "T1528",
     "Technique Name": "Steal Application Access Token",
     "Quotes": "Adversaries can steal application access tokens as a means of acquiring credentials to access remote systems and resources.",

   },
   {

     "Technique ID": "T1569",
     "Technique Name": "System Services",
     "Quotes": "Adversaries may abuse system services or daemons to execute commands or programs.",

     "Technique ID": "T1071.001",
     "Technique name": "Command and Control over Web Protocols",
     "Quotes": "Adversaries may use various web protocols as a means to communicate with C2 servers.",
     "Explanation": "This rule matches network traffic consistent with the behavior of Cobalt Strike, a common tool used by adversaries for remote access and control."
 ][
   {
     "sid": "56614",
     "Technique ID": "T1132",
     "Technique name": "Establish Command and Control",
     "Quotes": "Adversaries may establish command and control (C2) with a compromised system to maintain access and control over the system.",
     "Explanation": "This rule detects attempts to establish a connection with a Cobalt Strike beacon, which is a common tool used by adversaries to establish C2 with compromised systems."
   }
 ][
         "sid": "56614",
         "Technique ID": "T1219",
         "Technique name": "Masquerading",
         "Quotes": "",
         "Explanation": "This event is generated when activity relating to malware is detected."
     ][

         "Technique ID": "T1071.001",
         "Technique Name": "Command and Control Channel: Web Service",
         "Quotes": "Adversaries may use HTTP or HTTPS-based web service protocols to communicate with their command and control infrastructure.",
         "Explanation": "This rule detects attempts to establish a connection to a Cobalt Strike beacon, which is a tool used by adversaries to control compromised systems remotely"
     }
 ][
   {
     "sid": "56614",
     "Technique ID": "T1041",
     "Technique Name": "Exfiltration Over Command and Control Channel",
     "Quotes": "Adversaries may exfiltrate data over covert or legitimate channels.",
     "Explanation": "This rule detects beacon connections to Cobalt Strike, a common adversary tool used for remote access and control of compromised systems."
   },
   {
     "sid": "56614",
     "Technique ID": "T1133",
     "Technique Name": "External Remote Services",
     "Quotes": "Adversaries may leverage external-facing remote services to initially access and/or persist within a network.",
     "Explanation": "Cobalt Strike is often accessed through external remote services, such as its web service or its command-and-control server."
   }
 ][
     {
         "sid": "56614",
         "Technique ID": "T1105",
         "Technique Name": "Ingress Tool Transfer",
         "Quotes": ""adversaries may transfer tools or other files from an external system into a compromised environment"",
         "Explanation": "This rule looks for a characteristic HTTP POST request associated with Cobalt Strike beacon connections, which involves transferring tools and data between an external system and a compromised internal system."
     },
     {
         "sid": "56614",
         "Technique ID": "T1567",
         "Technique Name": "Establish Command-and-Control",
         "Quotes": ""Adversaries may establish command-and-control (C2) channels with compromised systems to facilitate remote control"",
         "Explanation": "Cobalt Strike is a commercial, post-exploitation tool used by adversaries to establish persistent, remote access to compromised systems for command-and-control purposes."
     }

         "sid": "56614",
         "Technique ID": "T1071",
         "Technique name": "Application Layer Protocol ",
         "Quotes": "Adversaries may communicate using OSI application layer protocols to avoid detection/network filtering by blending in with existing traffic.",
         "Explanation": "This rule targets Cobalt Strike, which is a legitimate penetration testing tool that can also be abused by adversaries for malicious purposes. The rule looks for specific HTTP headers and URI patterns that are commonly associated with Cobalt Strike beacon connections."
     ],
     [

         "Technique ID": "T1119",
         "Technique name": "Automated Collection ",
         "Quotes": "Once established within a system or network, an adversary may use automated techniques for collecting internal data",

     ],

         "Technique ID": "T1189",

     ],

         "Technique ID": "1560",
         "Technique name": "Archive Collected Data",

         "Technique name": "Automated Exfiltration",

        "Explanation": "This IDS rule detects attempts to establish a command shell on a compromised host using the Windows Command Shell."
    ]'}

     "Quotes": "\"Web shells provide adversary a remote access to the victim machine via a web server. They typically provide some rudimentary command execution, file manipulation, and directory traversal functionality. The access is achieved through a specially crafted URL sent to a vulnerable and compromised web server.\"",
     "Explanation": "This rule detects an attempt to establish an inbound connection to a PHP web shell known as C99Madnet, which allows remote access to the victim machine."
   }
 ][
         "sid": "59219",
         "Technique ID": "T1105",
         "Technique Name": "Establish Command and Control",
         "Quotes": "Adversaries may establish command and control (C2) over compromised assets to maintain persistent access and facilitate follow-on activities.",
         "Explanation": "This rule detects inbound connections to a web shell, which is a type of backdoor that allows remote access and control of a compromised system."
     ][
   {
     "sid": "59219",
     "Technique ID": "T1105",
     "Technique name": "Web Shell",
     "Quotes": "Adversaries may use web shells to execute arbitrary commands on a web server that is accessible through an external-facing web application.",
     "Explanation": "This rule looks for attempts to establish a connection to a web shell on the internal network."
   }
 ][
   {
     "sid": "59219",
     "Technique ID": "T1189",
     "Technique Name": "Web Shell",
     "Quotes": "\"Web shells are malicious scripts that provide remote administrative access to a web server. This technique typically involves placing an attacker-controlled script on a web server, providing the attacker with a command shell interface through which they can execute commands on the server\"",
     "Explanation": "This rule detects an attempt to establish an inbound connection to a web shell, likely to provide remote access or control to an attacker."
   }
 ][
     {
         "sid": "46605",
         "Technique ID": "T1105",
         "Technique name": "Ingress Tool Transfer",
         "Quotes": ""Adversaries may upload or otherwise transfer tools to a victim system during targeting. These tools may include adversarial command and control applications, custom scripts, implants, post-exploitation frameworks, and other utilities.",
         "Explanation": "This rule detects an inbound connection attempt to a PHP web shell, which is a malicious script that allows remote attackers to execute arbitrary commands on the victim system."
     },
     {
         "sid": "46605",
         "Technique ID": "T1041",
         "Technique name": "Remote System Discovery",
         "Quotes": ""Adversaries may attempt to gather information about remote systems to identify potential targets, discover weaknesses, or plan for future attacks. Remote system discovery techniques can collect information about the operating system, patch level, network configuration, and host software, either through direct connection or over the network.",
         "Explanation": "This rule detects an inbound connection attempt to a PHP web shell, which could be used by an attacker to gather information about the victim system."
     }
 ][
         "sid": "59219",
         "Technique ID": "T1484",
         "Technique name": "Masquerading",
         "Quotes": ""Adversaries may disguise malicious activity in order to suppress detection and analysis of their actions."",
         "Explanation": "This rule aims to detect malicious php webshells attempting to blend in with legitimate web traffic by hiding their malicious activities within parameters such as 'act', 'fullhexdump', and 'd'."
     ][
   {
     "sid": "59219",
     "Technique ID": "T1189",
     "Technique Name": "Exploit Public-Facing Application",
     "Quotes": "Adversaries may attempt to exploit a known vulnerability in a publicly accessible service to gain access to the system.",
     "Explanation": "This rule detects an attempt to connect to a known PHP web shell, which may be used to exploit vulnerabilities in web applications."
   }
 ][
         "sid": "59219",
         "Technique ID": "T1105",
         "Technique name": "Ingest Remote Image",
         "Quotes": "Adversaries may ingest an image or file from an external URL into a field, file, or other location on a system or application.",
         "Explanation": "The rule detects an attempt to upload a PHP web shell using an HTTP POST request with specific parameters, including 'act=', '&fullhexdump=', and '&d='."
     ][
         "sid": "59219",
         "Technique ID": "T1105",
         "Technique name": "Ingress Tool Transfer",
         "Quotes": "Adversaries may transfer additional tools or capabilities onto a victim system to support follow-on behaviors.  These tools may be open-source, customized, or even purchased.",
         "Explanation": "This rule detects an attempt to upload a PHP webshell with the name 'C99Madnet.php' to the target system. Webshells are often used by adversaries to maintain persistent access to a compromised system and execute commands remotely."
     ][
     "sid": "59219",
     "Technique ID": "T1190",
     "Technique name": "Exploit Public-Facing Application",
     "Quotes": "Adversaries may attempt to exploit a weakness in an Internet-facing host or system to initially access a network.",
     "Explanation": "This rule looks for inbound connection attempts to a PHP web shell that can be used to execute arbitrary commands on the target system."
 ][
   {
     "sid": "59219", 
     "Technique ID": "T1003", 
     "Technique name": "Remote Services", 
     "Quotes": "Adversaries may use a remote access tool, such as a web shell, to gain access to a remote system over HTTP(S) or other protocols.", 
     "Explanation": "In this rule, the traffic contains \"act=\", \"&fullhexdump=\", and \"&d=\", which are commonly associated with the C99Madnet PHP web shell, indicating an attempt to establish a remote connection to a system."
   }
 ]

]'}

     "Explanation": "This rule looks for the use of an XML External Entity declaration, which can be used to exfiltrate data from a system via an API."
   }
 ][
     "sid": "37313",
     "Technique ID": "T1120",
     "Technique name": "Data Exfiltration",
     "Quotes": ""Data Exfiltration techniques involve transferring data from a victim system to a location controlled by an adversary."",
     "Explanation": "This rule detects attempts to exfiltrate data from an SMTP server by using an external entity attack"
 ][
         "sid": "37313",
         "Technique ID": "T1133",
         "Technique name": "External Remote Services",
         "Quotes": "Adversaries may use external, publicly accessible resources to facilitate attacks.",
         "Explanation": "This rule detects an external entity data exfiltration attempt via SMTP, which involves using an external service to send malicious data out of a network."
     ][
         "sid": "37313",
         "Technique ID": "T1020",
         "Technique name": "Data Exfiltration",
         "Quotes": "Data Exfiltration is the removal of data from a system, usually over a network or other type of data transfer mechanism.",
         "Explanation": "This rule looks for attempts to exfiltrate data via an SMTP server using an XML external entity (XXE) attack."
     ][
   {
     "sid": "37313",
     "Technique ID": "T1566",
     "Technique Name": "Phishing",
     "Quotes": "\"Phishing messages are emails or text messages that trick the recipient into taking an action that results in the disclosure of personal or financial information, such as clicking a link to a malicious website or providing login credentials.
 
 In the context of this Snort rule, the rule detects attempts to send phishing emails using email encoding techniques to evade detection by traditional email filters.\"
     ",
     "Explanation": "This rule detects multiple external entity data exfiltration attempts."
   },
   {
     "sid": "37313",
     "Technique ID": "T1552",
     "Technique Name": "Spearphishing Attachment",
     "Quotes": "\"Spearphishing is an email-based phishing attack that targets a specific individual or organization. Spearphishing messages often contain malicious attachments designed to trick the recipient into installing malware or providing sensitive information.\"
 
 \"In the context of this Snort rule, the rule detects attempts to send spearphishing emails with malicious attachments using email encoding techniques to evade detection by traditional email filters.\"
     ",
     "Explanation": "This rule detects multiple external entity data exfiltration attempts."
   }
 ][
   {
     "sid": "37313",
     "Technique ID": "T1133",
     "Technique Name": "External Remote Services",
     "Quotes": "Adversaries may leverage external-facing remote services to initially access and/or persist within a network",
     "Explanation": "This rule detects an attempt to exploit an XXE vulnerability to exfiltrate data from an SMTP server."
   }
 ][
   {
     "sid": "37313",
     "Technique ID": "T1036",
     "Technique name": "Masquerading",
     "Quotes": "\"Masquerading techniques involve attempts to manipulate features of artifacts to make them appear legitimate or benign to users and/or security tools. External entity data exfiltration may involve attempts to embed data within other objects in order to transfer it without detection.\"",
     "Explanation": "This event is generated when there is an attempt to exfiltrate data from an SMTP server via an external entity."
   },
   {
     "sid": "37313",
     "Technique ID": "T1070",
     "Technique name": "Indicator Removal",
     "Quotes": "\"Indicator Removal techniques involve actions taken to delete or modify artifacts generated within systems to remove evidence of presence or hinder defenses.\"",
     "Explanation": "The rule looks for attempts to remove evidence of data exfiltration by deleting or modifying artifacts."
   }
 ][
   {
     "sid": "37313",
     "Technique ID": "T1569",
     "Technique Name": "Exfiltration Over Alternative Protocol",
     "Quotes": "Adversaries may transfer data over alternative protocols to bypass typical network-based exfiltration detection mechanisms.",
     "Explanation": "This rule looks for attempts to exfiltrate data via an SMTP server by embedding data within an XML External Entity declaration, a technique commonly used to exfiltrate data through firewalls that block typical exfiltration channels."
   }
 ][
     "sid": "37313",
     "Technique ID": "T1560",
     "Technique Name": "Archive Collected Data",
     "Quotes": "An adversary may compress and/or encrypt data that is collected prior to exfiltration.",
     "Explanation": "The rule detects exfiltration attempts using external entity (XXE) attacks, which involve hiding data within XML entities for exfiltration."
 ][
   {
     "Sid": 37313,
     "Technique ID": "T1041",
     "Technique Name": "Exfiltration Over Alternative Protocol",
     "Quotes": "Adversaries may exfiltrate data over protocols other than HTTP, such as SMTP, DNS, or ICMP.",
     "Explanation": "This rule looks for data exfiltration attempts over SMTP using an external entity declaration (XXE) attack, which is a technique commonly used to exfiltrate data over non-HTTP protocols."
   }
 ][
         "sid": "37313",
         "Technique ID": "T1114",
         "Technique name": "Email Collection",
         "Quotes": "Adversaries may target user email to collect sensitive information.",
         "Explanation": "This rule triggers when it detects the transmission of XML external entity data, which is often used for data exfiltration from SMTP servers."
     ]

     "Technique name": "Degraded Service",
     "Quotes": "\"Techniques that disrupt or degrade service can result in data breaches, ransomware attacks, fraudulent activity, and other business disruptions\"",
     "Explanation": "This rule detects attempts to exploit a denial of service vulnerability in NTP servers by sending packets with a crafted timestamp."
   }
 ][
   {
     "sid": "40811",

     "Technique Name": "Network Denial of Service",

     "Explanation": "This rule triggers when an NTP server receives a large number of packets with a zero value in the origin timestamp field, which can be used to launch a denial-of-service attack."
   }
 ]"sid": "40811",
         "Technique ID": "T1498",
         "Technique name": "Denial of Service",
         "Quotes": "Denial-of-service (DoS) attacks may consume targeted system resources, such as CPU cycles, memory, or bandwidth.",

     ][

   }
 ][

     "Technique Name": "Denial of Service",

     "Explanation": "This Snort rule is designed to detect and block attempts to exploit a denial of service vulnerability in NTP servers, which can be used to disrupt the availability of NTP services or cause NTP servers to crash."
   }
 ][
         "sid": "40811",
         "Technique ID": "T1495",
         "Technique name": "Firmware Corruption",
         "Quotes": "Adversaries may overwrite or corrupt the flash memory contents of system BIOS or other firmware in devices attached to a system in order to render them inoperable or unable to boot, thus denying the availability to use the devices and/or the system.",
         "Explanation": "This rule detects attempts to exploit a denial of service vulnerability in NTP servers by sending malformed packets that can cause the server to crash."

     "Technique ID": "T1490",

     "Quotes": "Adversaries may delete or remove built-in data and turn off services designed to aid in the recovery of a corrupted system to prevent recovery.",
     "Explanation": "The rule looks for traffic that is attempting to perform a denial of service against the Network Time Protocol service which can lead to disruption of system services."
 ][
     {
         "sid": "40811",
         "Technique ID": "T1498",
         "Technique name": "Degraded Service",
         "Quotes": "Adversaries may cause a system, service, or application to crash or otherwise become unavailable, causing a degradation or complete loss of service to users.",
         "Explanation": "This rule detects a Denial of Service attack against an NTP server, which could lead to the server becoming unavailable to legitimate clients."
     }
 ][
         "sid": "40811",
         "Technique ID": "T1498",
         "Technique name": "Resource Depletion",
         "Quotes": "Adversaries may use resource depletion attacks to decrease the availability of assets to a user or organization. The asset that the adversary targets will vary based on the adversary's objectives.",
         "Explanation": "This rule looks for NTP servers being flooded with requests, which can lead to a denial of service attack."
     ][
         "sid": "40811",
         "Technique ID": "T1498",
         "Technique name": "Denial of Service",
         "Quotes": "Adversaries may attempt to disrupt access to a computer or network resource by overwhelming it with requests or traffic.",
         "Explanation": "This event is generated when the system detects an attempt to exploit a denial of service vulnerability in the NTP service."
     ][
   {
     "sid": "40811",
     "Technique ID": "T1710",
     "Technique Name": "Denial of Service",
     "Quotes": "Denial-of-service (DoS) attacks disrupt access to a targeted system or network, often by flooding the target system or network with traffic or data. DoS attacks can be used to temporarily interrupt service or to force a restart or crash of the system or network.",
     "Explanation": "This rule is detecting a specific type of DoS attack targeting Network Time Protocol (NTP) servers known as an 'NTP Origin Timestamp' denial of service attack."
   }
 ]

{1425: '[
  {

    "Explanation": "Attempts to modify the Windows Registry could be indicative of a malicious actor trying to establish persistence or otherwise modify the system configuration."
  },
  {
    "sid": "1425",
    "Technique ID": "T1190",
    "Technique name": "Exploit Public-Facing Application",

  },
  {

    "Technique ID": "T1497",
    "Technique name": "Virtualization/Sandbox Evasion",

  },
  {

    "Technique name": "Compromise Client Software Binary",

  },
  {
    "sid": "1425",
    "Technique ID": "T1598",
    "Technique name": "Phishing for Information",
    "Quotes": "Adversaries may send phishing messages to elicit sensitive information that can be used during targeting.",
    "Explanation": "This rule looks for attempts to send phishing emails, which could be used to obtain sensitive information from users."
  },
  {
    "sid": "1425",
    "Technique ID": "T1621",
    "Technique name": "Multi-Factor Authentication Request Generation",
    "Quotes": "Adversaries may attempt to bypass multi-factor authentication (MFA) mechanisms and gain access to accounts by generating MFA requests sent to users.",
    "Explanation": "Attempts to generate MFA requests could be indicative of a malicious actor trying to bypass MFA and gain access to an account."
  },
  {
    "sid": "1425",
    "Technique ID": "T1608",
    "Technique name": "Stage Capabilities",
    "Quotes": "Adversaries may upload, install, or otherwise set up capabilities that can be used during targeting.",
    "Explanation": "Attempts to stage capabilities could be indicative of a malicious actor trying to prepare for further attacks."
  },
  {
    "sid": "1425",
    "Technique ID": "T1614",
    "Technique name": "System Location Discovery",
    "Quotes": "Adversaries may gather information in an attempt to calculate the geographical location of a victim host.",
    "Explanation": "Attempts to discover the system location could be indicative of a malicious actor trying to gain information about the target system."
  },
  {
    "sid": "1425",
    "Technique ID": "T1548",
    "Technique name": "Abuse Elevation Control Mechanism",
    "Quotes": "Adversaries may circumvent mechanisms designed to control elevate privileges to gain higher-level permissions.",
    "Explanation": "Attempts to abuse elevation control mechanisms could be indicative of a malicious actor trying to gain elevated privileges on the system."
  },
  {
    "sid": "1425",
    "Technique ID": "T1550",
    "Technique name": "Use Alternate Authentication Material",
    "Quotes": "Adversaries may use alternate authentication material, such as password hashes, Kerberos tickets, and application access tokens, in order to move laterally within an environment and bypass normal system access controls.",
    "Explanation": "Attempts to use alternate authentication material could be indicative of a malicious actor trying to bypass authentication and gain access to the system."
  },
  {
    "sid": "1425",
    "Technique ID": "T1606",
    "Technique name": "Forge Web Credentials",
    "Quotes": "Adversaries may forge credential materials that can be used to gain access to web applications or Internet services.",
    "Explanation": "Attempts to forge web credentials could be indicative of a malicious actor trying to gain unauthorized access to a web application or service."
  },
  {
    "sid": "1425",
    "Technique ID": "T1105",
    "Technique name": "Ingress Tool Transfer",
    "Quotes": "Adversaries may transfer tools or other files from an external system into a compromised environment.",
    "Explanation": "Attempts to transfer tools or files into a compromised environment could be indicative of a malicious actor trying to install malware or other tools."
  },
  {
    "sid": "1425",
    "Technique ID": "T1124",
    "Technique name": "System Time Discovery",
    "Quotes": "An adversary may gather the system time and/or time zone from a local or remote system.",
    "Explanation": "Attempts to discover the system time could be indicative of a malicious actor trying to gain information about the target system."
  },
  {
    "sid": "1425",
    "Technique ID": "T1127",
    "Technique name": "Trusted Developer Utilities Proxy Execution",
    "Quotes": "Adversaries may take advantage of trusted developer utilities to proxy execution of malicious payloads.",
    "Explanation": "Attempts to proxy execution of malicious payloads could be indicative of a malicious actor trying to bypass security controls."
  },
  {
    "sid": "1425",
    "Technique ID": "T1189",
    "Technique name": "Drive-by Compromise",
    "Quotes": "Adversaries may gain access to a system through a user visiting a website over the normal course of browsing."'}

     "Technique Name": "Web Shell",
     "Quotes": "\"Web shells are malicious scripts designed to facilitate unauthorized remote access to a compromised system through a web interface. The rule detects attempts to download and execute a JSP web shell, which would allow an adversary to gain unauthorized access to the system.\"",
     "Explanation": "This rule detects attempts to download and execute a JSP web shell."
   },
   {
     "sid": "59930",
     "Technique ID": "T1505",
     "Technique Name": "Server Software Component",
     "Quotes": "\"Adversaries may abuse legitimate extensible development features of servers to establish persistent access to systems. This rule detects the use of a JSP web shell, which is a type of server-side scripting that can be used for malicious purposes.\"",
     "Explanation": "This rule detects the use of a JSP web shell, which is a type of server-side scripting that can be used for malicious purposes."
   }
 ][
   {
     "sid": "59930",
     "Technique ID": "T1494",
     "Technique name": "Web Shell",

   },
   {
     "sid": "59930",
     "Technique ID": "T1071",
     "Technique name": "Command-Line Interface",

   }
 ][

         "Technique ID": "T1495",
         "Technique name": "Firmware Corruption",
         "Quotes": "Adversaries may overwrite or corrupt the flash memory contents of system BIOS or other firmware in devices attached to a system in order to render them inoperable or unable to boot, thus denying the availability to use the devices and/or the system.",
         "Explanation": "This rule looks for attempts to exploit a vulnerability in the firmware of a device connected to a network."
     }
 ][

     },

         "Technique Name": "User Execution",
         "Quotes": "Adversaries may execute commands directly through user interfaces and system administration tools.",

     }
 ][

     ],
     [
         "sid": "59930",
         "Technique ID": "T1560",
         "Technique name": "Web Shell",
         "Quotes": "Adversaries may upload and execute a web shell on a compromised system to provide a persistent remote access and control capability.",

     ]
 ][
         "sid": "59930",
         "Technique ID": "T1105",
         "Technique name": "Ingress Tool Transfer",
         "Quotes": "\"Ingress Tool Transfer involves transferring malicious tools and capabilities from an external location to a target system.",
         "Explanation": "This rule detects attempts to download and execute JSP web shells, which are often used to establish a backdoor on target systems."
     ][
         "sid": "59930",
         "Technique ID": "T1525",
         "Technique name": "Install Web Shell",
         "Quotes": "Web shells are often used as a persistence mechanism after successful exploitation of a web application.",
         "Explanation": "This event is generated upon detection of an attempt to download a malicious Java-based web shell, which would provide unauthorized remote access to the target system."
     ][
     {
         "sid": "59930",
         "Technique ID": "T1105",
         "Technique Name": "Ingress Tool Transfer",
         "Quotes": "\"Ingress Tool Transfer involves transferring a tool from an external location into a target environment for use in follow-on operations. This technique may involve the use of public or private infrastructure, or it may involve leveraging trusted relationships to move tools into a target environment. The tool may be transferred over command and control channels or other mechanisms to the target environment.\" - MITRE ATT&CK",
         "Explanation": "This rule detects attempts to download a Java web shell, which is a type of tool that can be used to execute commands on a compromised system. The web shell is downloaded using a Java FileOutputStream object, which is a class that can be used to write data to a file. The rule also detects the presence of the \"request.getParameter\" method, which is used to retrieve parameters from an HTTP request. This method can be used to pass commands to the web shell."
     }
 ]

    "Technique name": "Drive-by Compromise",
    "Quotes": "Adversaries may gain access to a system through a user visiting a website over the normal course of browsing",
    "Explanation": "This rule looks for attempts to exploit a remote code execution vulnerability in Oracle WebCenter Content ActiveX control.      "Quotes": "Adversaries may use trusted external services and resources for command and control.",
     "Explanation": "This event is an inbound connection to a known command and control server for the Perl.Backdoor.HARDPULSE backdoor. This technique involves using external services for command and control, which allows the adversary to maintain persistence and control over the compromised system."
   },
   {
     "sid": "57464",
     "Technique ID": "T1218",
     "Technique name": "Hidden Services",
     "Quotes": "Adversaries may attempt to conceal their activities within or behind legitimate traffic to avoid detection and attribution.",
     "Explanation": "The malware attempts to blend in with legitimate web traffic by using an HTTP-based command and control channel, making it difficult to detect and identify."
   },
   {

     "Technique ID": "T1570",
     "Technique name": "Command and Control",
     "Quotes": "Adversaries may establish command and control (C2) to maintain persistent access to victim systems.",
     "Explanation": "The rule detects an inbound connection to a known command and control server, which is used by the malware to receive commands and exfiltrate data."
   }
 ][
     {
         "sid": "57464",
         "Technique ID": "T1190",
         "Technique name": "Exploit Public-Facing Application",
         "Quotes": "Adversaries may attempt to exploit a weakness in an Internet-facing host or system to initially access a network.",
         "Explanation": "The rule triggers when a Perl-based backdoor (HARDPULSE) attempts to establish a connection with its command and control server. This behavior aligns with adversaries exploiting public-facing applications to gain initial access to a network."
     }
 ][
     "sid": "57464",
     "Technique ID": "T1132",
     "Technique name": "Establish Command and Control",
     "Quotes": "Adversaries may establish command and control (C2) with a victim system over various protocols and use various methods to maintain persistence and avoid detection.",
     "Explanation": "This alert is triggered when an inbound connection is made to a known malicious IP address, which is commonly used by Perl.Backdoor.HARDPULSE malware to establish a command and control channel."
 ][

         "Technique ID": "T1133",
         "Technique name": "External Remote Services",
         "Quotes": "Adversaries may leverage external-facing remote services to initially access and/or persist within a network.",

     ][
   {
     "sid": "57464",
     "Technique ID": "T1132",
     "Technique Name": "Establish Command and Control",
     "Quotes": "\"Establish Command and Control techniques involve establishing communications with a remote host for the purpose of delivering commands or retrieving results.\"",
     "Explanation": "This rule looks for connections from the external network to a public-facing web server on the internal network that match the pattern used by a Perl backdoor. The connection attempts to establish command and control with a remote host."
   },
   {
     "sid": "57464",
     "Technique ID": "T1490",
     "Technique Name": "Inhibit System Recovery",
     "Quotes": "\"Inhibit System Recovery techniques involve deleting or removing built-in data and turning off services designed to aid in the recovery of a corrupted system to prevent recovery.\"",
     "Explanation": "This rule may also be used by an attacker to inhibit system recovery by deleting or modifying critical system files or disabling recovery services."
   }
 ][
   {

     "Technique ID": "T1071.001",
     "Technique Name": "Web Shell",
     "Quotes": "Adversaries may use web shells to provide remote access to a compromised host and execute arbitrary commands.",

   },
   {

     "Technique ID": "T1105",
     "Technique Name": "Ingress Tool Transfer",
     "Quotes": "Adversaries may use various methods to transfer tools and capabilities to a victim system in order to prepare for or support other malicious operations.",
     "Explanation": "The backdoor may be transferred to the victim system via HTTP."
   },
   {

     "Technique ID": "T1098",
     "Technique Name": "Remote Services",
     "Quotes": "Adversaries may use remote services, such as legitimate cloud services, to host malicious content or provide command and control functionality.",
     "Explanation": "The backdoor may use a remote service for command and control."
   }
 ][
     {
         "sid": "57464",
         "Technique ID": "T1091",
         "Technique Name": "Remote Access Software",
         "Quotes": "Adversaries may use remote access software for a variety of purposes, including accessing remote systems, executing commands, transferring files, and managing system settings.",
         "Explanation": "This event is generated when activity relating to a malware backdoor is detected. The backdoor is a Perl script that establishes a command and control connection."
     }
 ][
     {
         "sid": "57464",
         "Technique ID": "T1129",
         "Technique name": "Connection Proxy",
         "Quotes": ""Adversaries may use a proxy server to provide indirect network access to internal resources while obscuring their true location or identity."",
         "Explanation": "This rule looks for connections to a known backdoor using a specific URI and POST parameters. The backdoor is known to use a proxy server to communicate with its C2 server."
     },
     {
         "sid": "57464",
         "Technique ID": "T1071",
         "Technique name": "Remote System Discovery",
         "Quotes": ""Adversaries may attempt to discover remote systems and services to identify potential targets for exploitation."",
         "Explanation": "The backdoor in this rule uses a specific URI and POST parameters to check for the presence of a specific file on the target system. This is a common technique used by attackers to identify potential targets for exploitation."
     }
 ][
   {
     "sid": "57464",
     "Technique ID": "T1071",
     "Technique Name": "Command and Scripting Interpreter",
     "Quotes": "\"Adversaries may use command and scripting interpreters available on the target system or as part of software tools to interpret commands provided by the adversary\"",
     "Explanation": "This rule triggers when Perl is used for malicious purposes."
   },
   {
     "sid": "57464",
     "Technique ID": "T1040",
     "Technique Name": "Exfiltration Over Command and Control Channel",
     "Quotes": "\"Adversaries may use an established command and control channel to exfiltrate data from the compromised environment while avoiding detection and disrupting forensic analysis\"",
     "Explanation": "The rule suggests that data may be exfiltrated back to the command and control server."
   },
   {
     "sid": "57464",
     "Technique ID": "T1105",
     "Technique Name": "Ingress Tool Transfer",
     "Quotes": "\"Adversaries may use an established communication channel, such as a command and control channel, to transfer additional tools or capabilities to the compromised environment\"",
     "Explanation": "The rule indicates an inbound connection, which may involve the transfer of additional malicious tools."
   }
 ]

{42834: '[
        "sid": "23934",
        "Technique ID": "T1071",
        "Technique name": "Application Layer Protocol",
        "Quotes": "Adversaries may communicate using OSI application layer protocols to avoid detection/network filtering by blending in with existing traffic",
        "Explanation": "This rule triggers when it detects an incoming connection that matches a web shell pattern, which includes a base64-decoded string and a malicious payload using the @eval syntax. Such techniques often rely on application layer protocols to evade detection and blend in with legitimate traffic."
    ],
    [
        "sid": "23934",
        "Technique ID": "T1105",
        "Technique name": "Ingress Tool Transfer",
        "Quotes": "Adversaries may transfer tools or other files from an external system into a compromised environment",
        "Explanation": "This rule detects an incoming connection that attempts to transfer a malicious payload into the compromised environment. The payload is concealed within an HTTP request that contains a base64-decoded string and a malicious command using the @eval syntax. This technique is commonly used to establish a backdoor or transfer additional tools for further exploitation."
    ]'}

        "sid": "42834",

        "Quotes": "Adversaries may communicate using OSI application layer protocols to avoid detection/network filtering by blending in with existing traffic.",

    ]'}

{47401: '[
        "sid": "47401",

        "Quotes": "Adversaries may use an OSI non-application layer protocol for communication between host and C2 server or among infected hosts within a network",

    ],
    [
        "sid": "47401",
        "Technique ID": "T1572",
        "Technique name": "Protocol Tunneling",
        "Quotes": "Adversaries may tunnel network communications to and from a victim system within a separate protocol to avoid detection/network filtering and/or enable access to otherwise unreachable systems",
        "Explanation": "The rule identifies an attempt to tunnel HTTP traffic within ICMP packets, which is an example of protocol tunneling."
    ]
]'}

    ]
]'}

             "Technique ID": "T1105",
             "Technique name": "Ingress Tool Transfer",
             "Quotes": "Adversaries may use remote access tools to gain remote access to, or control over, target systems from a remote location.",
             "Explanation": "The rule detects a specific beacon used by Cobalt Strike, a legitimate remote access tool that can also be used for malicious purposes."
         }
     ][
   {
     "sid": "56608",
     "Technique ID": "T1105",
     "Technique name": "Create Cobalt Strike Beacon",
     "Quotes": "Adversaries may use Cobalt Strike beacons as a means of establishing command-and-control (C2) communications with compromised systems.",
     "Explanation": "This rule detects inbound connection attempts to Cobalt Strike beacons, which are used for remote control and C2 communications."
   }
 ][
         "sid": "56608",
         "Technique ID": "T1071",
         "Technique Name": "Command and Control",
         "Quotes": "Adversaries may remotely control victim systems through various means, enabling them to execute arbitrary commands, modify data, and escalate privileges.",
         "Explanation": "This rule detects inbound connections from a Cobalt Strike beacon, which is a tool used by adversaries to communicate with and control compromised systems."
     ],
     [
         "sid": "56608",
         "Technique ID": "T1132",
         "Technique Name": "Data Encoding",
         "Quotes": "Adversaries may encode data to make the content of command and control traffic more difficult to detect.",
         "Explanation": "The rule looks for the presence of data encoded using the "|22" character, which is a common technique used by Cobalt Strike to encode its communications."
     ][
         "sid": "56608",
         "Technique ID": "T1071",
         "Technique name": "Command and Control",
         "Quotes": "Adversaries may use command and control (C2) infrastructure to communicate with compromised systems and issue instructions.",
         "Explanation": "This rule detects inbound connections to the Cobalt Strike beacon, which is a common tool used by adversaries for C2 purposes."
     ]
column7:
{56608: '[
    "sid": "56608",
    "Technique ID": "T1489",
    "Technique name": "Cobalt Strike Beacon",
    "Quotes": "Cobalt Strike's Beacon is an advanced post-exploitation implant that provides full remote control over a compromised system.",

]'}

column2:
[
         "sid": "50028",
         "Technique ID": "T1193",
         "Technique name": "File and Directory Discovery",
         "Quotes": ""Adversaries may attempt to identify files and directories on a system through a variety or mechanisms"",
         "Explanation": "This rule looks for a specific byte sequence that is associated with the Osx.Adware.TotalAdviseSearch malware, which is used to search for files and directories on a system."
     ][
         "sid": "50028",
         "Technique ID": "T1168",
         "Technique name": "Download Over C2 Channel",
         "Quotes": "Adversaries may use command and control infrastructure to download files or scripts to the target environment.",
         "Explanation": "This rule detects the download of a malicious file, specifically a variant of the Osx.Adware.TotalAdviseSearch adware, from a remote server."
     ][
   {
     "sid": "50028",
     "Technique ID": "T1140",
     "Technique Name": "Masquerading",
     "Quotes": "\"Masquerading techniques involve an adversary disguising themselves as a legitimate entity to avoid detection. The rule generates an alert when a file-data stream contains a pattern associated with Osx.Adware.TotalAdviseSearch, which is a malicious application.",
     "Explanation": "This rule looks for attempts to download a variant of Osx.Adware.TotalAdviseSearch adware."
   }
 ][
         "sid": "50028",
         "Technique ID": "T1105",
         "Technique name": "Download File",
         "Quotes": "Adversaries may attempt to download files containing malicious software to execute later, which can include tools to maintain access or establish persistence on a system.",
         "Explanation": "This rule looks for attempts to download an adware file variant."
     ][
   {
     "sid": "50028",
     "Technique ID": "T1481",
     "Technique Name": "Drive-by compromise",
     "Quotes": "\"Drive-by compromise is a method of infecting a computer when a user visits an infected website.",
     "Explanation": "This rule detects the attempted downloading of a malicious binary typically used in drive-by compromise attacks."
   },
   {
     "sid": "50028",
     "Technique ID": "T1110",
     "Technique Name": "Exploitation for Client Execution",
     "Quotes": "\"Exploitation for Client Execution techniques are methods used by adversaries to execute malicious code on a victim's device leveraging browser vulnerabilities.\"",
     "Explanation": "This rule detects the attempted downloading of a malicious binary typically used in browser-based attacks."
   },
   {
     "sid": "50028",
     "Technique ID": "T1566",
     "Technique Name": "Phishing",
     "Quotes": "\"Phishing is an attempt by an adversary to acquire information such as username/password or financial data from a user by impersonating a trustworthy entity in an electronic communication.\"",
     "Explanation": "Phishing attacks often use drive-by compromise techniques to infect victims' machines."
   }
 ][
   {
     "sid": "50028",
     "Technique ID": "T1190",
     "Technique name": "Exploit Public-Facing Application",
     "Quotes": "Adversaries may attempt to exploit a weakness in an Internet-facing host or system to initially access a network.",
     "Explanation": "This rule detects an attempt to download a malicious Mach-O executable associated with the Osx.Adware.TotalAdviseSearch adware family."
   },
   {
     "sid": "50028",
     "Technique ID": "T1495",
     "Technique name": "Firmware Corruption",
     "Quotes": "Adversaries may overwrite or corrupt the flash memory contents of system BIOS or other firmware in devices attached to a system in order to render them inoperable or unable to boot, thus denying the availability to use the devices and/or the system",
     "Explanation": "Malware that corrupts firmware can cause a system to become unstable or unusable."
   }
 ][
         "sid": "50028",
         "Technique ID": "T1106",
         "Technique Name": "Ingress Tool Transfer",
         "Quotes": "Adversaries may transfer tools or other files from an external system into a compromised environment.",
         "Explanation": "This rule detects the transfer of a malicious Mach-O file, potentially containing adware, from an external system to a host within the internal network."
     ][
         "sid": "50028",
         "Technique ID": "T1105",
         "Technique name": "Ingest Remote Content",
         "Quotes": "Adversaries may obtain tools or data from external, possibly malicious, remote systems.",

     ][
   {
     "sid": "50028",
     "Technique ID": "T1105",
     "Technique Name": "Ingest Data from External Source",
     "Quotes": "Adversaries may move data between internal and external systems. The data may be exfiltrated to an external system, such as a command and control server, to facilitate objectives such as data collection, command and control, and exploitation.",
     "Explanation": "This rule detects and blocks attempts to download a malicious executable."
   }
 ][
   {
     "sid": "50028",
     "Technique ID": "T1587",
     "Technique Name": "Develop Capabilities",
     "Quotes": "Adversaries may build capabilities that can be used during targeting. This may include developing custom tools or acquiring commercial tools. Adversaries may also modify or repurpose existing tools to meet their needs.",
     "Explanation": "This event is generated when activity relating to downloading a malicious program is detected."
   },
   {
     "sid": "50028",
     "Technique ID": "T1140",
     "Technique Name": "Deobfuscate/Decode Files or Information",
     "Quotes": "Adversaries may use Obfuscated Files or Information to hide artifacts of an intrusion from analysis.",
     "Explanation": "Binary data and obfuscated code is often included in malware for stealthiness or anti-detection purposes."
   }
 ][
         "sid": "50028",
         "Technique ID": "T1189",
         "Technique name": "Drive-by Compromise",
         "Quotes": "Adversaries may gain access to a system through a user visiting a website over the normal course of browsing.",
         "Explanation": "This rule looks for attempts to download a malicious Mach-O executable commonly associated with the Osx.Adware.TotalAdviseSearch adware, which typically occurs through drive-by downloads on compromised websites."
     ]

{16268: '[
    "sid": "16268",
    "Technique ID": "T1003",
    "Technique name": "Initial Access",
    "Quotes": "Initial access is the first phase of an adversary campaign. It represents how an adversary initially gains access to a network or system; this access may be for the sole purpose of reconnaissance, or to gain a foothold in the network for exploitation.",
    "Explanation": "This rule detects malware that installs itself on a system. This is often done through a vulnerability in a web application or by tricking a user into downloading and executing a malicious file."
]'}

{57975: '[
        "sid": "57975",
        "Technique ID": "T1048",
        "Technique name": "Exfiltration Over Alternative Protocol",
        "Quotes": "Adversaries may steal data by exfiltrating it over a different protocol than that of the existing command and control channel, such as Exfiltration over HTTP(S).",
        "Explanation": "The rule detects an outbound request from a compromised host to an external IP address over HTTP port, which is a common method for exfiltrating data over an alternative protocol."
    ]'}
column7:
{57975: '[
    "sid": "57975",
    "Technique ID": "T1048",
    "Technique name": "Exfiltration Over Alternative Protocol",
    "Quotes": "Adversaries may exfiltrate data over non-standard or alternative protocols to evade detection.",
    "Explanation": "This rule looks for traffic to a known malicious domain that is associated with the Raccoon trojan. The traffic is using an HTTP POST request with a non-standard User-Agent, Accept, and Referer header, which could be an attempt to evade detection."
]'}

         "Explanation": "This rule detects traffic containing malicious content related to malvertising, which involves the use of deceptive advertising to distribute malware."
     },

     }
 ][
     "sid": "23620",
     "Technique ID": "T1129",

 ][

         "Technique name": "Malvertising",
         "Quotes": "Adversaries may place malicious advertisements in legitimate online advertising networks to redirect users to malicious websites or download malware.",

     ][

         "Technique ID": "T1124",

These communications appear to come from legitimate sources such as banks, credit card companies, and social media websites.",
         "Explanation": "This rule detects attempts to redirect users to a malicious website that impersonates a legitimate entity (Twitter) to steal their credentials."

column2:
[
     "sid": "47640",
     "Technique ID": "T1569",
     "Technique name": "System Services",
     "Quotes": "Adversaries may abuse system services or daemons to execute commands or programs.",
     "Explanation": "SSL certificates are used to establish secure connections between a client and a server. A null issuer rdnSequence field in an SSL certificate can indicate a misconfiguration or an attempt to bypass security controls."
 ][
   {
     "sid": "47640",
     "Technique ID": "T1140",
     "Technique name": "Masquerading",
     "Quotes": "Masquerading techniques involve concealing the identity of the source of network traffic or hiding aspects of the true operator of the traffic.",
     "Explanation": "The rule looks for SSL certificates with null issuer rdnSequence fields, which can be used to hide the identity of the server."
   }
 ][
   {
     "sid": "47640",
     "Technique ID": "T1239",
     "Technique name": "Trust Manipulation",
     "Quotes": "Adversaries may manipulate trust credentials to spoof their identity for domain authentication or assume identities associated with abused accounts.",
     "Explanation": "This rule looks for SSL certificates with null issuer rdnSequence fields, which is a common way to bypass SSL/TLS certificate validation and impersonate a trusted entity."
   }
 ][
     "sid": "47640",
     "technique ID": "T1203",
     "technique name": "Create or Modify Artifacts",
     "Quotes": "Adversaries may forge or modify SSL/TLS certificates to evade detection or to compromise the validity of certificate validation.",
     "Explanation": "This rule detects the creation or modification of fraudulent SSL certificates with null issuer rdnSequence fields, indicating potential evasion of SSL/TLS certificate validation mechanisms."
 ][
         "sid": "47640",
         "Technique ID": "T1580",
         "Technique Name": "X.509 Certificate Validation",
         "Quotes": "Adversaries may examine and utilize information from X.509 certificates, during both certificate and TLS negotiation, to gather information about the system or infrastructure.",
         "Explanation": "This rule looks for an SSL certificate with null issuer rdnSequence fields, which could indicate a misconfiguration or an attempt to bypass security controls."
     ],
     [
         "sid": "47640",
         "Technique ID": "T1581",
         "Technique Name": "Certificate Transparency Logging",
         "Quotes": "Adversaries may leverage Certificate Transparency (CT) logs to obtain information about certificates issued to a domain or organization.",
         "Explanation": "This rule may also be indicative of an attempt to obtain certificates from a Certificate Transparency log for malicious purposes."
     ][
   {

     "Quotes": "Adversaries may create or modify digital certificates to impersonate a trusted authority, thereby allowing them to authenticate themselves to systems, services, and users.",
     "Explanation": "This rule detects SSL certificates with null issuer rdnSequence fields, which can be used to masquerade as a trusted authority."
   }
 ][
         "sid": "47640",
         "Technique ID": "T1591",
         "Technique Name": "Gather Victim Org Information",
         "Quotes": "Adversaries may gather information about the victim's organization that can be used during targeting.",
         "Explanation": "This rule detects the presence of a null issuer rdnSequence field in an SSL certificate, which can be an indicator of an attempt to impersonate a legitimate organization."
     ][
   {
     "sid": "47640",
     "Technique ID": "T1594",
     "Technique name": "Digital Certificate",
     "Quotes": "Adversaries may use digital certificates, sometimes after stealing them from trusted organizations, to sign malware or perform other actions. Adversaries have also used self-signed digital certificates to avoid detection by security controls.",
     "Explanation": "This rule detects SSL certificates with null issuer rdnSequence fields, which is often a sign of malicious activity."
   }
 ][
     "sid": "47640",
     "Technique ID": "T1549",
     "Technique name": "Install Root Certificate",
     "Quotes": "Adversaries may install their own root certificate on the system.",
     "Explanation": "This rule detects a malformed SSL certificate with null issuer rdnSequence fields from the server side. This can indicate that the adversary is attempting to install their certificate to establish a rogue CA, which can be used in MITM attacks to intercept and manipulate traffic."

     "Technique ID": "T1548",
     "Technique name": "Establish C2 Channel",
     "Quotes": "Adversaries may establish command and control channels over encrypted protocols such as SSL/TLS to maintain persistent access to victim systems.",

   },

     "sid": "47640",
     "Technique ID": "T1132",
     "Technique name": "Data Encoding",
     "Quotes": "Adversaries may encode data to make the content of command and control traffic more difficult to detect.",

 ][

     "Technique ID": "T1608",
     "Technique name": "X.509 Certificate Validation",

 ]
column6:
{47640: '[
        "sid": "47640",
        "Technique ID": "T1553.003",
        "Technique name": "Exploit Public-Facing Application: SSL Certificate Spoofing",
        "Quotes": ""Exploit Public-Facing Application techniques are used to target web applications that are accessible from the Internet. One method of exploiting web applications is by passing a crafted certificate to the victim that appears to be from the legitimate organization. By doing so, the adversary can impersonate the legitimate organization, which may allow them to perform a variety of attacks such as phishing, malware distribution, and data theft."",
        "Explanation": "This rule looks for SSL certificates with null issuer fields, which can be used to spoof legitimate certificates and trick victims into trusting malicious websites."
    ]'}

[
         "sid": "50098",
         "Technique ID": "T1588",
         "Technique name": "Phishing",
         "Quotes": "Adversaries may attempt to trick users into opening a file that is infected with malware, clicking on a link that leads to a malicious site, or providing personal or account information.",
         "Explanation": "This rule detects attempts to poison a Responder host, which is a server that responds to DNS queries for a specific domain name and provides attackers with a way to redirect users to a malicious website."
     ][
   {
     "sid": "50098",
     "Technique ID": "T1545",
     "Technique name": "Responder Poisoning",
     "Quotes": "\"Responder poisoning is a type of DNS poisoning attack in which an adversary poisons the cache of a DNS server by responding to DNS queries with forged or malicious DNS responses.\"",
     "Explanation": "This rule looks for traffic consistent with Responder poisoning, which is a technique used to redirect traffic to malicious servers."
   }
 ][
         "sid": "50098",
         "Technique ID": "T1546",
         "Technique name": "Poisoning",
         "Quotes": ""Poisoning techniques involve modifying legitimate content with malicious code, such as shell commands or scripts, or modifying the configuration of legitimate services."",
         "Explanation": "This rule detects a Responder poisoner attack, where an attacker poisons the ARP cache of a victim to redirect traffic to a malicious server."
     ][
     "sid": "50098",
     "Technique ID": "T1499",
     "Technique name": "Deception",
     "Quotes": ""Deception techniques involve misleading the defender as to the adversary's true objectives, actions, or location."",
     "Explanation": "The HTTP response includes the message ""Welcome To Spider Shell!"", which is a common indicator of a web shell attack, attempting to deceive the defender about the adversary's intent to gain remote access to the system."
 ][
   {
     "sid": "50098",
     "Technique ID": "T1558",
     "Technique name": "Impair Defenses",
     "Quotes": "Adversaries may disable or interfere with security capabilities such as firewalls, antivirus software, and intrusion detection systems to facilitate their operations.",
     "Explanation": "The rule triggers when an adversary attempts to poison an HTTP connection by exploiting a vulnerability. This action can be part of an attempt to disable or interfere with security defenses to facilitate adversary operations."
   },
   {
     "sid": "50098",
     "Technique ID": "T1562",
     "Technique name": "Masquerading",
     "Quotes": "Adversaries may disguise themselves as other users, services, or systems for the purpose of evading detection or deceiving other users within an environment.",
     "Explanation": "The rule detects an attempt to use the Spider Shell, a web shell, to gain unauthorized access to a system. This technique can be used to bypass security controls by masquerading as a legitimate service or application."
   }
 ][
   {
     "sid": "50098",
     "Technique ID": "T1592",
     "Technique name": "Gather Victim Host Information",
     "Quotes": "Adversaries may gather information about the victim's hosts that can be used during targeting.",
     "Explanation": "This rule detects a poisoner attack using the Responder tool, which is used to gather information about the victim's hosts."
   },
   {
     "sid": "50098",
     "Technique ID": "T1589",
     "Technique name": "Gather Victim Identity Information",
     "Quotes": "Adversaries may gather information about the victim's identity that can be used during targeting.",
     "Explanation": "This rule can also gather information about the victim's identity, such as their IP address and operating system."
   },
   {
     "sid": "50098",
     "Technique ID": "T1590",
     "Technique name": "Gather Victim Network Information",
     "Quotes": "Adversaries may gather information about the victim's networks that can be used during targeting.",
     "Explanation": "This rule can also gather information about the victim's network, such as their network topology and security controls."
   }
 ][
     "sid" : "50098",
     "Technique ID" : "T1499",
     "Technique Name" : "Responder Abuse",
     "Quotes" : "Adversaries may abuse the Responder protocol for various malicious purposes, such as sniffing credentials, capturing NetNTLM hashes, performing SMB relay attacks, and even executing arbitrary code in the context of other systems.",
     "Explanation" : "This rule detects a Responder poisoner HTTP attack attempt, which is used to poison Responder clients and potentially execute arbitrary code on remote systems."
 ][
     {
         "sid": 50098,
         "Technique ID": "T1491",
         "Technique Name": "Web Shell",
         "Quotes": "Web shells are malicious scripts that give adversaries a remote administrative interface to a compromised web server, typically through a web application vulnerability or misconfiguration.",
         "Explanation": "The rule detects the presence of a known web shell string, indicating an attempt to establish a remote administrative interface."
     }
 ][
     "sid": "50098",
     "Technique ID": "T1546",
     "Technique name": "Exploit Public-Facing Application",
     "Quotes": "Adversaries may attempt to exploit a weakness in an Internet-facing host or system to initially access a network.",
     "Explanation": "The rule detects attempts to exploit a vulnerability in web applications that allows attackers to poison the output returned by the server. This is a common technique used by attackers to compromise web applications and gain access to sensitive data."
 ][
   {
     "sid": "50098",
     "Technique ID": "T1491",
     "Technique name": "Defacement",
     "Quotes": "\"Adversaries may modify visual content available internally or externally to an enterprise network, thus affecting the integrity of the original content.\"",
     "Explanation": "This rule detects attempts to use the Responder tool to poison DNS responses and redirect traffic to a malicious website, potentially leading to defacement of legitimate websites."
   }
 ][
   {
     "sid": "50098",
     "Technique ID": "T1498",
     "Technique Name": "Responder Manipulation",
     "Quotes": "Adversaries may manipulate Responder Advertisements (RAs) to configure rogue DHCP servers and redirect network traffic to malicious resources or provide inaccurate information in response to queries for domain name resolution to redirect traffic to malicious resources",
     "Explanation": "The rule appears to be detecting a Responder poisoner HTTP attack, which is a technique that involves manipulating Responder Advertisements (RAs) in order to redirect network traffic to malicious resources."
   }
 ]

column5:
{47845: '[
        "sid": "47845",
        "Technique ID": "T1106",
        "Technique name": "Native API",
        "Quotes": "Adversaries may interact with the native OS application programming interface (API) to execute behaviors.",
        "Explanation": "This rule looks for a variant of Win.Downloader.DDECmdExec downloading using msiexec.exe. It uses the native API to execute the download."
    ],
        "sid": "47845",
        "Technique ID": "T1140",
        "Technique name": "Deobfuscate/Decode Files or Information",
        "Quotes": "Adversaries may use Obfuscated Files or Information to hide artifacts of an intrusion from analysis",
        "Explanation": "This rule looks for a variant of Win.Downloader.DDECmdExec downloading using msiexec.exe. The download is obfuscated using a pipe character. The rule uses a regular expression to deobfuscate the download."
    ],
        "sid": "47845",
        "Technique ID": "T1189",
        "Technique name": "Drive-by Compromise",
        "Quotes": "Adversaries may gain access to a system through a user visiting a website over the normal course of browsing",
        "Explanation": "This rule looks for a variant of Win.Downloader.DDECmdExec downloading using msiexec.exe. The download is triggered by a user visiting a website."
    ]'}

File Download techniques may be used to retrieve various types of files, such as malware executables, scripts, configuration files, or data exfiltration tools.",
     "Explanation": "The rule is triggered when specific data is observed in the file payload of an SMTP transaction, suggesting an attempt by malware to download a file remotely."

 ][

         "Technique Name": "Exfiltration over Command and Control Channel",
